content.description: This starts as a left leaning OW, about 7" and about halfway up ledges out then turns to "normal" crack for a few moves to topout. Sandbagged IMO, if you have fat thighs it might feel ok for 5.9.
content.protection: A 7" piece for the biz, and maybe a finger to hand sized piece for the topout.
content.location: This is the obvious wide crack on the NF of Pacman, just in front of an amazing, perfectly smooth, perfectly flat "patio" of rock.

content.description:
Hidden from view on the backside of Pac Man Rock is this very overhanging, perfect splitter that's actually the backside of The Marathon Crack (5.12a).

Thin jams at an unrelenting angle are the attraction, which although a long walk is reasonable for such a striking line.

A delicate start in a thin crack/seam that's mostly tips gives way to actual finger locks higher as the angle steepens. The climb though short is demanding and requires good technique and a cool head to succeed.

Two stars out of five only because it's not longer.
content.protection: Gear to 1 inch; to 2.5 inches for the anchor
content.location: The west face of Pac Man Rock is home to this short but striking splitter that slashes it's way up a steep, featureless slab.

content.description: Established as a toprope, the flake will take some gear, but the face above is unprotected. As a lead it would be "R".
